entry.title: Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser arrested for fraud

media:group.media:title: Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser arrested for fraud
media:group.media:description:
Former White House adviser Steve Bannon was arrested on Thursday on charges that he and three others illicitly took money from donors in an online fundraising scheme "We Build The Wall".
The charges were contained in an indictment unsealed in Manhattan federal court.
Federal prosecutors alleged that Bannon and three others "orchestrated a scheme to defraud hundreds of thousands of donors" in connection with an online crowdfunding campaign that raised more than $25m to build a wall along the southern border of the United States.

entry.title: Russian opposition leader 'fighting for life' after alleged poisoning

media:group.media:title: Russian opposition leader 'fighting for life' after alleged poisoning
media:group.media:description:
Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny is in a coma and on a ventilator in a Siberian hospital after falling ill during a flight from suspected poisoning, according to his spokeswoman. Kira Yarmysh said on Thursday that Navalny, 44, was flying from Siberia to Moscow after a work trip to Tomsk when his plane made an emergency landing after he fell ill.
Al Jazeera's Rory Challands reports.

entry.title: An average of seven children go missing daily in Mexico: Report

media:group.media:title: An average of seven children go missing daily in Mexico: Report
media:group.media:description:
More than 73,000 people are listed as missing in Mexico and around 20 percent of them are minors. Activists say the number of children who disappear every day has doubled over the past two years. Most are believed to have been trafficked for sexual exploitation or sold into forced labour. Al Jazeera's Manuel Rapalo reports.

entry.title: Has justice been served in the assassination of Rafik Hariri? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Has justice been served in the assassination of Rafik Hariri? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
It was a long-awaited verdict after an investigation which has cost hundreds of millions of dollars. Fifteen years after the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the UN-backed international tribunal in the Hague convicted Salim Ayyash, a member of Hezbollah. Three other defendants belonging to the armed group were acquitted of killing Lebanon's former Prime Minister. All four were tried in their absence. Hezbollah denies any involvement in the massive bomb blast in Beirut which killed 21 other people.
So, how will the murder verdict of Lebanon's former Prime Minister be received when tension there is already high?
Presenter: Hashem Ahelbarra Guests; Rami Khouri - Senior Public Policy Fellow and Professor of Journalism at the American University in Beirut Firas Maksad - Adjunct Professor, George Washington University Elias Hanna - Retired General from Lebanon's army

entry.title: How did reopening schools become a political issue in the US? | The Bottom Line

media:group.media:title: How did reopening schools become a political issue in the US? | The Bottom Line
media:group.media:description:
Millions of American children returned to school in the past few weeks, and millions more are scheduled to begin in September. Many school districts have given families a choice between face-to-face and virtual education. In many places, new coronavirus cases forced schools to shut down just days after opening.
President Donald Trump has threatened to punish schools that will not open for face-to-face learning, but many teachers have said it is not safe to return yet.
Host Steve Clemons speaks to Randi Weingarten, the president of one of the biggest teachers' unions, the American Federation of Teachers, to get her perspective on the debate.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Italy's Sikh Slaves | People and Power

media:group.media:title: Italy's Sikh Slaves | People and Power
media:group.media:description:
The vast agricultural plains of the Agro-Pontino in central Italy is now one of the country's main areas of food production.
Yet it was not always the case.
This 100 mile-long stretch of land facing the Tyrrhenian Sea was marshland until a century ago when fascist dictator Benito Mussolini organised a mass migration from northern Italy to drain the swamps and turn them into fertile farmland.
But many of those who live today are not Italian, they are Indian - at least 11,000 of them, and possibly up to four times more.
Mostly Sikhs from Punjab in northern India, they are economic migrants who have come here to work in local farms and send money home to give their families a better life.
Some manage to do just that. But for many others, their dreams are crushed.
Instead, they face abuse and exploitation from both profit-driven agri-businesses and organised crime - labouring for pitiful wages, often without official documentation, and trapped in a system from which there is no escape.
Filmmakers Alessandro Righi and Emanuele Piano went to investigate for People & Power.

entry.title: Argentina rushes to produce COVID-19 vaccine

media:group.media:title: Argentina rushes to produce COVID-19 vaccine
media:group.media:description:
Argentina is battling a surge in coronavirus cases, with at least 312,000 infections now confirmed and more than 6,000 related deaths. The government says intensive care admissions and hospital bed occupancy rates have become unsustainable. Last week, Argentina announced a local laboratory will start manufacturing the highly-promising Astra Zeneca Oxford vaccine. Assuming the vaccine is proven effective and clears safety trials, Argentina will then distribute it to countries throughout South America with the exception of Brazil, which is producing its own vaccine.
Al Jazeera's Teresa Bo reports from Buenos Aires.

entry.title: Colombia tribunal: Former rebels testify to recruiting minors

media:group.media:title: Colombia tribunal: Former rebels testify to recruiting minors
media:group.media:description:
Former commanders of Colombia’s rebel group FARC, that is the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, began their testimony in front of a peace tribunal on Wednesday. They addressed the forced recruitment and abuse of children into their ranks, as well as abuse, during the country’s 50-year-long civil conflict.
Al Jazeera’s Alessandro Rampietti reports from Bogota.

entry.title: US: One dead, tens of thousands flee as fires rage in California

media:group.media:title: US: One dead, tens of thousands flee as fires rage in California
media:group.media:description:
Hundreds of wildfires are raging across the US state of California, forcing tens of thousands of people to leave their homes. The state is appealing for extra resources and firefighters are battling extraordinary conditions, including extreme heat, high winds, and lightning strikes.
Al Jazeera’s Rob Reynolds reports from Los Angeles in the US state of California.

entry.title: Merkel, Macron to discuss Europe’s future

media:group.media:title: Merkel, Macron to discuss Europe’s future
media:group.media:description:
Later on Thursday, German Chancellor Angela Merkel will meet French President Emmanuel Macron at his presidential retreat in the Mediterranean to discuss the future of the European Union.
Al Jazeera’s Dominic Kane reports from Berlin, Germany.

entry.title: EU rejects Belarus vote result, warns of imminent new sanctions

media:group.media:title: EU rejects Belarus vote result, warns of imminent new sanctions
media:group.media:description:
The European Union has rejected the result of the election in Belarus. Following an emergency meeting, it has announced sanctions against those it deems responsible for suppressing protests, as well as making money available for pro-democracy groups in Belarus. The EU's moves were seen as meddling by the Russian government, which, a day earlier, had warned Germany not to interfere.
Al Jazeera's Nadim Baba reports.

entry.title: Mali coup leaders promise elections after Keita overthrow

media:group.media:title: Mali coup leaders promise elections after Keita overthrow
media:group.media:description:
Malian opposition leader Mahmoud Dicko said he would step back from politics, after meeting soldiers who deposed the president in a coup. The new military rulers have ordered civil servants to return to work, and promised to oversee democratic elections, within a "reasonable timeframe". The international community has condemned Tuesday's coup, with some announcing sanctions.
Al Jazeera's Ahmed Idris reports.

entry.title: US-Iraq relations: Iraqi PM visits Washington, DC

media:group.media:title: US-Iraq relations: Iraqi PM visits Washington, DC
media:group.media:description:
Iraq's Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi is in the United States to meet President Donald Trump. They are expected to discuss Iraq's relationship with Iran, the withdrawal of US troops and coordination against the ISIL (ISIS) armed group.
Al Jazeera’s Dorsa Jabbari reports from Baghdad on what is at stake for the Iraqi prime minister during this highly anticipated trip.

entry.title: Kamala Harris sees US at 'inflexion point' in upcoming elections

media:group.media:title: Kamala Harris sees US at 'inflexion point' in upcoming elections
media:group.media:description:
The Democratic Party has made history by nominating Kamala Harris as its vice presidential candidate, as an array of party leaders laid out their case for Joe Biden to be the next president of the United States and urged people to organise and vote. Democrats must defeat President Donald Trump in the November election or face a chaotic, destructive future amid a deadly pandemic and a rising climate crisis, Harris and a parade of Democrats including women, immigrants and young people warned on the third night of the virtual Democratic National Convention.
Al Jazeera’s Alan Fisher reports from Washington, DC.

#DNC2020 #KamalaHarris #Biden2020

entry.title: Russian opposition leader Navalny poisoned: Spokeswoman

media:group.media:title: Russian opposition leader Navalny poisoned: Spokeswoman
media:group.media:description:
Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny is in a coma and on a ventilator in ICU in a hospital in Siberia after falling ill from suspected poisoning during a flight, his spokeswoman said on Thursday. She believes poison was mixed into his tea. Navalny is a staunch critic of President Vladimir Putin. Last year, he was taken to hospital after another alleged poisoning, while he was serving a jail sentence for encouraging people to take part in a pro-democracy protest.
To discuss the latest updates, we speak to Aleksandra Stojanovich-Godfroid, a journalist who joins us on Skype from Moscow; later we speak to Dara Macdool, head of Europe and principal Russia analyst at Verisk Maplecroft, a global risk consultancy, who joins us from London.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
